message.content: We refer to the United States Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) for help. According to USPSTF, a screening colonoscopy is recommended for adults aged 50-75 years for the early detection of colorectal cancer. Prostate-specific antigen is not recommended for routine screening, carcinoembryonic antigen is not recommended for routine screening of general population, and abdominal ultrasonography is recommended only for men who have ever smoked and are between the ages of 65 to 75 to detect abdominal aortic aneurysm.

We refer to the official website of the United States Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) for help. According to USPSTF, the recommended screening test for colorectal cancer is colonoscopy starting at age 50 and repeating every 10 years. Prostate-specific antigen is recommended for prostate cancer screening in men aged 55-69 only after discussing the potential benefits and risks with their healthcare provider. Carcinoembryonic antigen is not recommended for routine colorectal cancer screening. Abdominal ultrasonography for abdominal aortic aneurysm is recommended for men aged 65-75 years who have ever smoked cigarettes.

We refer to the United States Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommendations for help. The USPSTF recommends colorectal cancer screening for adults aged 50 to 75 years, with various screening methods including colonoscopy. Prostate-specific antigen is not recommended for routine screening and abdominal ultrasonography for abdominal aortic aneurysm is only recommended for men aged 65 to 75 years who have ever smoked. Carcinoembryonic antigen is not recommended as a screening test for colorectal cancer.

We refer to the United States Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) for help. According to the USPSTF, colonoscopy screening is recommended for adults aged 50 to 75 years to prevent colorectal cancer. Prostate-specific antigen screening for prostate cancer is only recommended in certain high-risk populations, carcinoembryonic antigen screening for colorectal cancer is not recommended for routine screening, and abdominal ultrasonography for abdominal aortic aneurysm is only recommended in men aged 65 to 75 years who have ever smoked.

We refer to the United States Preventive Services Task Force website for help. According to USPSTF, periodic colonoscopy is recommended for adults aged 50-75 to screen for colorectal cancer, especially for those with a family history of colorectal cancer. Prostate-specific antigen test is recommended for males aged 55-69 to screen for prostate cancer but this patient is only 50 years old. Carcinoembryonic antigen test is used to monitor patients previously diagnosed with colorectal cancer, not for screening in asymptomatic patients. Abdominal ultrasonography for abdominal aortic aneurysm is recommended for males aged 65-75 with a history of smoking tobacco.

We refer to the United States Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) for help. According to USPSTF, screening for colorectal cancer should begin at age 50 and continue until age 75. Colonoscopy is the preferred screening test, although other options such as fecal occult blood testing, sigmoidoscopy, and virtual colonoscopy may be used. Prostate-specific antigen is not recommended for routine screening in men of any age, while carcinoembryonic antigen is not recommended for routine screening for colorectal cancer. Abdominal ultrasonography for abdominal aortic aneurysm is recommended for men aged 65 to 75 who have ever smoked.

We refer to the United States Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommendations on screening tests. According to USPSTF, adults aged 50-75 years should be screened for colorectal cancer using fecal occult blood testing, sigmoidoscopy, or colonoscopy. Therefore, colonoscopy is the recommended screening test for this patient. Prostate-specific antigen is recommended for prostate cancer screening in men aged 55-69 years. Carcinoembryonic antigen is not a recommended screening test for colorectal cancer. Abdominal ultrasonography for abdominal aortic aneurysm is recommended for men aged 65-75 years who have ever smoked.

We refer to the United States Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) website for help. The USPSTF recommends screening for colorectal cancer using fecal occult blood testing, sigmoidoscopy, or colonoscopy starting at age 50 and continuing until age 75. Therefore, the correct answer is D, colonoscopy for colorectal cancer. Prostate-specific antigen testing is not recommended for routine screening in men of this age group. Carcinoembryonic antigen testing and abdominal ultrasonography are not recommended for routine screening in asymptomatic individuals.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. According to USPSTF, men between the ages of 50 and 75 years should undergo screening for colorectal cancer, which is typically done by colonoscopy. The other options are not recommended for routine screening in this patient population.

We refer to the United States Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) website for this question. According to their current recommendations, colonoscopy is recommended for colorectal cancer screening for adults aged 50 to 75 years. Prostate-specific antigen testing is not recommended for routine prostate cancer screening, carcinoembryonic antigen testing is not recommended for routine colorectal cancer screening, and abdominal ultrasonography is not recommended for routine abdominal aortic aneurysm screening in asymptomatic adults. As the patient in the question is 50 years old, colonoscopy is the recommended screening test.
